perturbation.original_text: Before using any promotional and advertising materials, you will submit to us or our designated agency, for our prior approval, all information pertaining to promotional materials and advertising initiated by you, including, but not limited to, newspapers, radio and television advertising, Internet or any other medium, specialty and novelty items, signs, boxes, napkins, bags and wrapping papers. In the event written disapproval of any such advertising and promotional material has not been given by us to you within twenty (20) days from the date such information has been received by us, the materials will be deemed approved.
perturbation.changed_text: Before using any promotional and advertising materials, you should submit to us or our designated agency, for our approval, information pertaining to promotional materials and advertising initiated by you, including newspapers, radio and television advertising, Internet or any other medium, specialty and novelty items, signs, boxes, napkins, bags and wrapping papers. If written disapproval of any such advertising and promotional material has not been provided by us to you, the materials might be deemed approved.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a clear directive ('you will submit') and a specific timeframe for approval. The modified text uses 'should submit' and 'might be deemed approved,' weakening the obligation and creating ambiguity. This creates uncertainty regarding the franchisor's approval process, potentially leading to unauthorized advertising and brand inconsistencies. The change of 'has not been given by us to you within twenty (20) days from the date such information has been received by us, the materials will be deemed approved' to 'has not been provided by us to you' weakens this aspect as well.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Lanham Act (15 U.S.C. § 1114) - Trademark Infringement, as unauthorized advertising could dilute the brand and infringe on trademarks if proper review is not ensured.

perturbation.original_text: You will contribute to the Buffalo Wild Wings Advertising and Development Fund ("Fund") (which may be one of several regional Funds, if we elect to establish separate Funds to serve various regions in which multiple franchisees are located) an amount equal to three percent (3%) of your Gross Sales, as defined in Paragraph X. Your required payments to the Fund will be made on or before the fifteenth day of the month for the preceding month.
perturbation.changed_text: You might contribute to the Buffalo Wild Wings Advertising and Development Fund ("Fund") (which could be one of several regional Funds, if we consider establishing separate Funds to serve various regions in which multiple franchisees are located) approximately three percent (3%) of your Gross Sales, as defined in Paragraph X. Payments to the Fund could be made around the fifteenth day of the month for the preceding month.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates contribution to the Advertising Fund. The modified text uses 'might contribute' and 'could be made,' making the contribution and payment timeframe discretionary, rather than compulsory, and introduces vague language that introduces legal ambiguity regarding financial obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Franchise Disclosure Laws (various state laws) – The ambiguous nature of the financial contribution contradicts the franchise laws which requires a clear outline of franchisee fees.

perturbation.original_text: The Franchised Restaurant shall at all times be under your direct, on-premises supervision, unless, upon sixty (60) days prior written notice and approval by us you designate a trained and competent employee to act as full-time general manager. Your designation of a general manager shall be subject to our prior written approval, and shall further be subject to the designated general manager successfully completing our training course. All costs for the attendance of the designated general manager at our training course shall be at your cost, except as set forth in Section IV(A).
perturbation.changed_text: The Franchised Restaurant may be under your supervision when feasible, perhaps designating a trained employee to act as manager if deemed appropriate by both parties. A manager designation might require some form of approval. Costs related to manager training may possibly be your responsibility.
perturbation.explanation: Original text specifies a requirement for on-premises supervision or designation of a full-time manager with specific conditions. Modified text uses vague terms like 'may be,' 'when feasible,' 'perhaps,' and 'some form of approval,' making the supervision requirements ambiguous and unenforceable. This introduces ambiguity around operational oversight, which could lead to inconsistent quality control and brand standards.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (Common Law) – The weakening of the supervision requirement allows for potential neglect of the franchise location, contradicting the implied duty to operate the franchise in a manner that upholds brand standards and protects the franchisor's interests.
